description: Recorded since circa 1510, a back-formation from investigation, from Latin investīgātiō (“a searching into”), from investīgātus, the past participle of investigare, equivalent to in- +‎ vestigate. Displaced native Old English undersēċan (literally “to search under or between”).

verbs.description: investigate (third-person singular simple present investigates, present participle investigating, simple past and past participle investigated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inquire into or study in order to ascertain facts or information.
examples: to investigate the causes of natural phenomena

entries.meaning: (transitive) To examine, look into, or scrutinize in order to discover something hidden or secret.
(intransitive) To conduct an inquiry or examination.
examples: "Why don't you investigate?" he demanded. And investigate I did.
